questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being tackled while playing football. He has severe right shoulder pain and is unable to move the shoulder. He also reports nausea but has not vomited. There is no personal or family history of serious illness. His only medication is a multivitamin. On physical examination, the right upper extremity is externally rotated and slightly abducted. Palpation of the right shoulder joint shows tenderness and an empty glenoid fossa. The right humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process. The left upper extremity appears normal. Radial pulses are palpable bilaterally. An x-ray of the right shoulder is performed. The physician administers analgesia and obtains informed consent for closed reduction. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?

choices.text: Paralysis of the wrist flexors and intrinsic hand muscles
Decreased sensation of the dorsum of thumb, index, and middle fingers
Decreased sensation of the lateral upper arm
Inability to flex the thumb, index, and middle fingers
Decreased sensation of the lateral lower arm

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Paralysis of the wrist flexors and intrinsic hand muscles is seen in Klumpke palsy. This condition is typically caused by traumatic injury to the C8 and T1 nerve roots that form the lower trunk of the brachial plexus. The brachial plexus and its trunks lie more proximal than the nerve typically injured during a shoulder dislocation; therefore plexus injuries due to shoulder dislocation and reduction are exceedingly rare. In adults, Klumpke palsy most commonly occurs due to hyperabduction of the arm e.g., during an attempt to break a fall from a height by grabbing support.

B) INCORRECT:

Decreased sensation in fingers I–III together with reduced finger extensor strength and wrist drop are characteristic of radial nerve injury, which can be caused by humeral shaft fracture. Signs of shaft fracture include severe local pain and swelling, deformity, crepitus, and shortening of the arm (if displacement is present). This patient's presentation is most consistent with anterior shoulder dislocation, in which radial nerve injury is uncommon. In addition, radial nerve injury is not a complication of closed shoulder reduction.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP joints

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2nd and 3rd fingers. The 1st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumb

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function

C) CORRECT:

Axillary nerve injury (ANI) is the most common nerve injury in shoulder dislocation because of the close proximity of the axillary nerve to the humeral head. ANI also rarely occurs as a complication of closed reduction, which is the first-line treatment for most patients with shoulder dislocation. Typical manifestations of ANI include decreased sensation over the lateral shoulder and impaired abduction and external rotation of the arm. In shoulder dislocation, impaired abduction and external rotation may occur because of mechanical reasons and are not necessarily a sign of ANI. Because ANI has a high rate of spontaneous recovery, patients are initially managed conservatively following closed reduction and immobilization to treat shoulder dislocation.

Other complications of shoulder dislocation include axillary artery and vein injury, fractures of the shoulder joint, and rotator cuff tears, all of which rarely also occur as a complication of reduction procedures.
Image Description:

Lateral and ventral view of the right shoulder

The dashed line shows the normal position and the solid red line shows the pathological position that occurs with anterior dislocation. Axillary nerve palsy is a known complication of both shoulder dislocation and reduction. Axillary nerve function should be evaluated before and after attempting reduction, by testing sensation over the lateral surface of the shoulder (yellow overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

The inability to flex the thumb, index, and middle fingers results in the hand of benediction sign, which is characteristically seen in proximal median nerve injury (e.g., due to supracondylar humerus fracture). Median nerve injury is very unlikely in anterior shoulder dislocation and/or as a complication of reduction because it runs inferiorly to the shoulder joint.
Image Description:

AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve

E) INCORRECT:

Decreased sensation of the lateral lower arm can result from musculocutaneous nerve injury. The musculocutaneous nerve is well-protected throughout its course and is rarely injured. Most musculocutaneous pathologies occur as a result of traumatic compression of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. The brachial plexus and its trunks lie more proximal than the nerve typically injured during a shoulder dislocation; therefore plexus injuries due to shoulder dislocation and reduction are exceedingly rare.
questions.hint: This patient presents after trauma with external rotation and abduction of the arm, in combination with shoulder pain and palpation of the humeral head below the coracoid process, indicating anterior shoulder dislocation. This is the most common type of shoulder dislocation.

questions.text: A 27-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of pain and an inability to move his left shoulder for the past 45 minutes. He says the symptoms started after he had a tonic-clonic seizure. He has autism spectrum disorder and epilepsy. There is no family history of serious illness. His current medications include sodium valproate and levetiracetam. He appears uncomfortable. Vital signs are within normal limits. Examination shows that the left arm is adducted and internally rotated. The anterior left shoulder is flattened with prominence of the coracoid process. The right upper extremity shows no abnormalities. Sensation over the lateral surface of both shoulders is normal. Radial pulses are palpable bilaterally. Oropharyngeal examination shows a tongue laceration. An anteroposterior view x-ray of this patient's left shoulder and arm is most likely to show which of the following?

choices.text: Posterolateral depression fracture of the humeral head
Circular appearance of the humeral head
Anteroinferior lesion of the glenoid labrum
Superior subluxation of the humeral head

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Posterolateral depression fracture of the humeral head, known as Hill-Sachs defect, is caused by impaction of the humeral head on the glenoid rim during anterior shoulder dislocation. In patients with anterior dislocation, the affected arm is typically held in external rotation and slight abduction. Reverse Hill-Sachs defect (a depressed fracture in the anteromedial portion of the humeral head) may be seen in posterior shoulder dislocation.
Image Description:

X-ray of the right shoulder (transcapular view) of a patient with locked posterior dislocation

The humeral head has posteriorly dislocated from the glenoid (green overlay) and the arm is locked in a raised position. An impaction fracture (reverse Hill-Sachs lesion) is seen as a large trough-like defect in the humeral head (red line).

A: acromion, C: clavicula, H: humeral head, S: scapula

B) CORRECT:

Circular appearance of the humeral head, or the light bulb sign, is a diagnostic radiographic sign of posterior shoulder dislocation. As the humeral head dislocates posteriorly, it is forced into internal rotation and appears circular, producing a contour resembling a lightbulb on anteroposterior (AP) view x-ray. Other findings suggestive of posterior shoulder dislocation include the rim sign, trough line, reverse Hill-Sachs defect, and reverse Bankart lesion. Uncomplicated posterior dislocations should be managed conservatively with closed reduction.

AP, scapular Y view, and axillary view x-rays are typically obtained for a suspected posterior shoulder dislocation. However, in some cases, a posterior dislocation may not be detected on AP view, therefore, an axillary lateral view is preferred for diagnosis.
Image Description:

X-ray shoulder (AP view; left: dislocation; right: post reduction)

Internal rotation of the humerus during posterior dislocation produces a contour resembling a lightbulb on the AP radiograph (overlay). In addition, poor congruency of the humeral head with the glenoid is seen in this patient. After reduction, the greater tubercle (tuberosity) is visible laterally and the humeral head is well-aligned with the glenoid fossa.

C) INCORRECT:

Anteroinferior lesion of the glenoid labrum, known as a Bankart lesion, can occur as a result of anterior shoulder dislocation. In patients with anterior dislocation, the affected arm is typically held in external rotation and slight abduction. Reverse Bankart lesions (posteroinferior lesions of the glenoid labrum) may be seen in posterior shoulder dislocation.
Image Description:

Click on the overlay icon below the taskbar on the left to toggle the overlay on and off.

MRI left shoulder (STIR and T1, coronal plane; PD FS, axial and sagittal plane)

On the fat-saturated sequences (STIR and both PD images), there is hyperintensity in the posterolateral humeral head and anteroinferior glenoid rim with corresponding hypointensity on the T1 image. These findings indicate contusion. In addition, a depression in the cortex of the affected region of the humeral head (Hill-Sachs depression fracture) is seen. There is also a fracture through the affected anteroinferior glenoid (osseous or bony Bankart Lesion).

This pattern of injury occurs during anterior dislocation as the humeral head externally rotates and descends inferiorly, impacting the anteroinferior glenoid rim with its posterolateral surface.

D) INCORRECT:

Midshaft humeral fracture can manifest with severe local pain and limitation of movement. However, proximal (e.g., anatomical neck) rather than midshaft fractures are associated with posterior shoulder dislocation. Moreover, there are no other signs of a midshaft humeral fracture (e.g., swelling, bruising, upper arm deformity, extremity shortening).

E) INCORRECT:

Superior subluxation of the humeral head, also known as high-riding humeral head, can manifest with shoulder pain and a restricted range of motion. However, this is typically found in patients with rotator cuff tears rather than posterior shoulder dislocation.
questions.hint: This patient presents with left shoulder pain after experiencing violent muscle contractions during a tonic-clonic seizure, which can be forceful enough to cause a fracture and/or dislocation. An adducted, internally rotated arm and a flattened shoulder with a prominent coracoid process suggest posterior shoulder dislocation.

questions.text: A 19-year-old man is brought to the emergency department because of severe right shoulder pain and inability to move the shoulder after a fall while climbing outdoors. Examination shows the right upper extremity is externally rotated and slightly abducted. There is loss of the normal rounded appearance of the shoulder. The right humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process. Sensation to pinprick over which of the following skin areas is most likely to be reduced?

choices.text: Medial aspect of the upper arm
Dorsal aspect of forearm and hand

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The medial aspect of the upper arm is supplied by the medial brachial cutaneous nerve, a direct branch of the brachial plexus. Injuries are rare but can occur as a result of surgical error or with trauma to the brachial plexus itself.

B) CORRECT:

The nerve most commonly damaged as a result of anterior shoulder dislocation is the axillary nerve, which has a dermatome over the lateral shoulder. This injury thus often causes loss of sensation in this area.

C) INCORRECT:

The hypothenar eminence and ulnar-sided fingers are innervated by the ulnar nerve. Injuries to this nerve can be seen with fractures of the medial condyle of the humerus or the hamate. The ulnar nerve is unaffected by anterior shoulder dislocations.

D) INCORRECT:

The thenar eminence and radial-sided fingers are innervated by the median nerve. Median nerve injuries can arise as a result of supracondylar humeral fractures, carpal tunnel syndrome, or lacerations at the wrist. The median nerve is unaffected by anterior shoulder dislocations.

E) INCORRECT:

The skin above the clavicle is innervated by the supraclavicular nerve, along with the skin of the posterior shoulder and the anterolateral chest wall. The supraclavicular nerve runs superior to the humeral head and is unaffected by an anterior dislocation.

F) INCORRECT:

Musculocutaneous nerve injury would affect sensation over the lateral aspect of the forearm. These injuries are uncommon and would not be affected by an anterior shoulder dislocation.

G) INCORRECT:

The dorsal aspect of the forearm and hand are innervated by the radial nerve. While radial nerve injuries may occur in anterior shoulder dislocations, they are less common than axillary nerve injuries. Radial nerve palsy is usually due to its compression in the axilla or upper arm ('Saturday night palsy') and fractures of the humeral midshaft.
questions.hint: A combination of external rotation and abduction of the arm, flattening of the shoulder contour, and palpation of the humeral head below the coracoid process is indicative of anterior shoulder dislocation. The axillary nerve is stretched over the displaced head of the humerus (neurapraxia), making it especially prone to injury.

questions.text:
A 37-year-old right-handed man presents with persistent pain in his right shoulder. One year ago, he suffered an anterior dislocation of his right shoulder when he was tackled during a football game. The arm was immobilized for 2 weeks; he then participated in physical therapy continually for 3 months and intermittently thereafter. He now plays tennis regularly and feels pain in his shoulder, particularly when reaching up to serve the tennis ball. The shoulder aches for days afterward.
On examination, he has full range of motion with shoulder abduction and flexion. When the right arm is abducted to 90 degrees and maximally externally rotated, the patient feels as though the shoulder will dislocate, and he has some pain in the anterior shoulder. In the same position, when a posterior force is applied to the humerus, the feeling of impending dislocation is relieved. Sensation to light touch in the arm is normal.
MRI of the shoulder shows an anterior labral tear and a small bony fragment at the anterior inferior rim of the glenoid.
Which one of the following management approaches is most appropriate for this patient?

choices.text: Temporary shoulder immobilization in a sling
Glucocorticoid injection into the glenohumeral joint
Glucocorticoid injection into the subacromial bursa

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A shoulder sling may be used in the early period after traumatic dislocation but is unlikely to provide long-term relief.

B) INCORRECT:

A glucocorticoid injection can be useful to treat rotator cuff tendinitis or to provide temporary relief of pain in osteoarthritis of the shoulder but is unlikely to help in this case and may unnecessarily delay surgery.

C) CORRECT:

Anterior dislocation of the shoulder typically results from trauma to the arm while the arm is abducted and externally rotated. This sort of injury can occur during contact sports, motor vehicle collisions, and generalized tonic-clonic seizures. Patients with genetic disorders of connective tissue, such as Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, are at increased risk for shoulder dislocation.

Anterior dislocation of the shoulder is frequently associated with avulsion of the anterior capsulolabral complex (Bankart lesion). The damage may cause pain and a sensation of instability when the shoulder is stressed, such as in the apprehension-relocation test described in this case. Conservative management with physical therapy may suffice, but in a patient with recurrent symptoms and ongoing evidence of instability on examination, surgical stabilization may be required.

Key learning point: The most appropriate management approach for post-traumatic and recurrent anterior instability of the shoulder that has not responded to physical therapy is surgical stabilization.

D) INCORRECT:

Ultrasound therapy has not proven to be effective in treating shoulder dislocation injuries.

E) INCORRECT:

A glucocorticoid injection can be useful to treat rotator cuff tendinitis or to provide temporary relief of pain in osteoarthritis of the shoulder but is unlikely to help in this case and may unnecessarily delay surgery.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man presents to the emergency department one hour after falling on his outstretched arm during a basketball game. He is in pain and describes weakness and numbness of his right shoulder. He had no prior injuries or other issues with his right upper extremity. He is right-hand dominant.
The patient has squaring of his right shoulder, generalized tenderness, and a diminished range of motion of the right arm in all directions. He has paresthesias and diminished sensation to light touch over the lateral aspect of the shoulder. He has 5/5 strength with elbow flexion and extension, finger adduction and abduction, thumb opposition, and wrist flexion. The distal pulses are intact.
A radiograph of the shoulder is obtained (figure).
Which one of this patient’s nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The ulnar nerve supplies motor innervation to the intrinsic hand musculature and extrinsic muscles of the forearm along the ulnar side of the hand. It also provides sensation in the hand along the ulnar side (the small finger and part of the ring finger). Injury to this nerve would cause numbness to the small finger and weakness in finger abduction and adduction.

B) INCORRECT:

The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the elbow flexors in the anterior compartment of the arm (coracobrachialis, biceps, and brachialis) as well as the lateral cutaneous nerve, which provides sensation to the lateral forearm. Injury to this nerve would affect elbow flexion and forearm sensation.

C) INCORRECT:

The suprascapular nerve provides motor innervation to both the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles, as well as sensory innervation to the posterosuperior aspect of the shoulder. Injury to this nerve may manifest with weakness on external rotation or abduction, especially in the 90- to 180-degree planes, depending on the site of injury.

D) CORRECT:

The axillary nerve is vulnerable to damage as it passes underneath the glenoid and through the quadrilateral space, particularly from injuries such as an anterior shoulder dislocation. Axillary nerve damage results in paresthesias and diminished sensation to light touch over the lateral aspect of the shoulder, and it may also lead to weakness with abduction and external rotation of the arm. The radiograph shows a probable anterior inferior dislocation, although axillary radiographs would be necessary to confirm the direction of dislocation.

Key learning point: The nerve that, when injured, results in paresthesias and diminished sensation to light touch over the lateral aspect of the shoulder is the axillary nerve.

E) INCORRECT:

The radial nerve provides motor innervation to the triceps muscle, brachioradialis, and extrinsic extensors of the wrist and hand, as well as sensory innervation to the dorsum of the hand. Injury to the radial nerve manifests with decreased sensation to the dorsum of the hand and weakness with resisted elbow, wrist, and thumb extension.

questions.text:
A 17-year-old girl presents with mild but persistent deep, dull, achy pain in her right shoulder one week after dislocating it in a skiing accident. She underwent successful reduction, confirmed by postreduction radiographs, and was discharged in a sling.
On examination, she has full range of motion of the shoulder with a sensory deficit over the posterior deltoid. She has some weakness with resisted arm abduction. Her drop arm test is negative. There is no point tenderness. She is able to extend the wrist and fingers without any difficulty. A cervical spine examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute brachial radiculitis (Parsonage-Turner syndrome) is characterized by abrupt onset of unilateral shoulder pain, which becomes progressively painful with worsening neurologic deficits. It is often self-limited. It can manifest similarly to axillary nerve injury after a trauma, such as shoulder dislocation, but it is far less common after shoulder dislocation than axillary nerve injury is. Acute brachial radiculitis is often seen postoperatively and is poorly understood.

B) INCORRECT:

C7 radiculopathy would not manifest with deltoid weakness. Patients with a C7 radiculopathy complain of numbness in the second and third fingers, weakness with resisted wrist extension, or both.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the radial nerve can be injured in an anterior shoulder dislocation, such an injury would manifest clinically as weakness on examination of wrist and finger extension.

D) INCORRECT:

A negative drop arm test makes a complete supraspinatus rotator cuff tear unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Anterior shoulder dislocation can injure the axillary nerve, which runs inferior to the humeral head. Axillary nerve damage manifests with deltoid muscle weakness and numbness of the posterior shoulder. Older age, delayed relocation, and humeral head fractures are risk factors for nerve injury after shoulder dislocation.

Anterior inferior dislocations, the most common type of shoulder dislocation, are most closely associated with axillary nerve injury. Affected patients often present with deep aching in the posterior shoulder.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis for a patient who presents with deep posterior shoulder pain and deltoid weakness following a shoulder dislocation is axillary nerve injury.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old boy presents to the emergency department one hour after falling on his outstretched arm during a basketball game. He is in pain and describes weakness and numbness of his right shoulder. He had no prior injuries or other issues with his right upper extremity. He is right-hand dominant.
The patient has squaring of his right shoulder, generalized tenderness, and a diminished range of motion of the right arm in all directions. He has paresthesias and diminished sensation to light touch over the lateral aspect of the shoulder. He has 5/5 strength with elbow flexion and extension, finger adduction and abduction, thumb opposition, and wrist flexion. The distal pulses are intact.
A radiograph of the shoulder is obtained (figure).
Which one of this patient’s nerves is most likely to be injured?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The musculocutaneous nerve supplies the elbow flexors in the anterior compartment of the arm (coracobrachialis, biceps, and brachioradialis) as well as the lateral cutaneous nerve, which provides sensation to the lateral forearm. Injury to this nerve would affect elbow flexion and forearm sensation.

B) CORRECT:

The axillary nerve is vulnerable to damage as it passes underneath the glenoid and through the quadrilateral space, particularly from injuries such as an anterior shoulder dislocation. Axillary nerve damage results in paresthesias and diminished sensation to light touch over the lateral aspect of the shoulder, and it may also lead to weakness with abduction and external rotation of the arm. The radiograph shows a probable anterior inferior dislocation, although axillary radiographs would be necessary to confirm the direction of dislocation.

Key learning point: The nerve that, when injured, results in paresthesias and diminished sensation to light touch over the lateral aspect of the shoulder is the axillary nerve.

C) INCORRECT:

The suprascapular nerve provides motor innervation to both the supraspinatus and infraspinatus muscles, as well as sensory innervation to the posterosuperior aspect of the shoulder. Injury to this nerve may manifest with weakness on external rotation or abduction, especially in the 90- to 180-degree planes, depending on the site of injury.

D) INCORRECT:

The ulnar nerve supplies motor innervation to the intrinsic hand musculature and extrinsic muscles of the forearm along the ulnar side of the hand. It also provides sensation in the hand along the ulnar side (the small finger and part of the ring finger). Injury to this nerve would cause numbness to the small finger and weakness in finger abduction and adduction.

E) INCORRECT:

The radial nerve provides motor innervation to the triceps muscle and extrinsic extensors of the wrist and hand, as well as sensory innervation to the dorsum of the hand. Injury to the radial nerve manifests with decreased sensation to the dorsum of the hand and weakness with resisted elbow, wrist, and thumb extension.

questions.text:
A healthy 13-year-old boy presents to urgent care with shoulder deformity. He reports that he was playing football when he collided with another player and felt his shoulder pop out. Radiographs show an anteriorly dislocated shoulder.
The shoulder is reduced at bedside. A postreduction radiograph (figure) shows successful shoulder reduction with a new Bankart lesion (damage of the labral attachment to the anterior glenoid margin). The patient’s arm is placed in a sling.
What is the most appropriate next step for this patient?

choices.text: Repeat plain-film radiographs of the left shoulder in one week
Initiate shoulder-strengthening exercises with physical therapy
Refer for fitting of a shoulder immobilizer

questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

There are several types of shoulder dislocations. Anterior shoulder dislocations, the most common type, occur when the arm is forced into abduction and external rotation, which leads to anterior displacement of the humeral head relative to the glenoid fossa.

In adolescents, dislocations are typically intracapsular and involve capsular and labral detachment. One suggestive finding is a Bankart lesion with damage of the labral attachment to the anterior glenoid margin. This lesion can be identified on plain-film radiographs but is better visualized with MRI.

A Bankart lesion increases the risk for recurrent shoulder dislocation. Recurrent dislocation occurs more frequently in adolescents than adults. Patients who sustain a first-time traumatic shoulder dislocation with a Bankart lesion should be referred to orthopedic surgery for further evaluation and management.

Other considerations for orthopedic referral in cases of shoulder dislocation include hyperlaxity on examination and involvement in contact sports. Further imaging with either MRI or CT, to evaluate for bony and labral injuries, is also warranted but is typically ordered by the orthopedic specialist.

Key learning point: Patients with a traumatic first-time shoulder dislocation who have a Bankart lesion are at increased risk for recurrent dislocation and should be referred to orthopedic surgery for further evaluation and management.

B) INCORRECT:

Repeat plain-film radiographs do not add further information and are not indicated.

C) INCORRECT:

Although this patient will certainly need physical therapy before returning to play, such therapy should be delayed until he is evaluated by orthopedic surgery, given his high risk for recurrent dislocation and the presence of a Bankart lesion. If there is no indication for surgery, physical therapy would be a reasonable next step. Physical therapy should be aimed at allowing the patient to progress through passive range-of-motion exercises, followed by active range-of-motion exercises, and finally to strengthening and flexibility exercises by week 6.

D) INCORRECT:

Given his high risk for recurrent dislocation and the presence of a Bankart lesion, this patient should be evaluated by orthopedic surgery. If there is no indication for surgery, physical therapy would be a reasonable next step.

E) INCORRECT:

Immobilization alone without surgical intervention is not appropriate in a patient with a Bankart lesion.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents with mild but persistent deep, dull, achy pain in her right shoulder one week after dislocating it in a skiing accident. She underwent successful reduction, confirmed by postreduction radiographs, and was discharged in a sling. On examination, she has full range of motion of the shoulder with a sensory deficit over the posterior deltoid. She has some weakness with resisted arm abduction. Her drop arm test is negative. There is no point tenderness. She is able to extend the wrist and fingers without any difficulty. A cervical spine examination is unremarkable. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Acute brachial radiculitis (Parsonage-Turner syndrome) is characterized by abrupt onset of unilateral shoulder pain, which becomes progressively painful with worsening neurologic deficits. It is often self-limited. It can manifest similarly to axillary nerve injury after a trauma, such as shoulder dislocation, but it is far less common after shoulder dislocation than axillary nerve injury is. Acute brachial radiculitis is often seen postoperatively and is poorly understood.

B) INCORRECT:

C7 radiculopathy would not manifest with deltoid weakness. Patients with a C7 radiculopathy complain of numbness in the second and third fingers, weakness with resisted wrist extension, or both.

C) INCORRECT:

Although the radial nerve can be injured in an anterior shoulder dislocation, such an injury would manifest clinically as weakness on examination of wrist and finger extension.

D) INCORRECT:

A negative drop arm test makes a complete supraspinatus rotator cuff tear unlikely.

E) CORRECT:

Anterior shoulder dislocation can injure the axillary nerve, which runs inferior to the humeral head. Axillary nerve injury manifests with deltoid muscle weakness and numbness of the posterior shoulder. Older age, delayed relocation, and humeral head fractures are risk factors for nerve injury after shoulder dislocation.

Anterior inferior dislocations, the most common type of shoulder dislocation, are most closely associated with axillary nerve injury. Affected patients often present with deep aching in the posterior shoulder.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis for a patient who presents with deep posterior shoulder pain and deltoid weakness following a shoulder dislocation is axillary nerve injury.
questions.hint: This patient most likely had an anterior shoulder dislocation.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being tackled while playing football. He has severe right shoulder pain and is unable to move the shoulder. He also reports nausea but has not vomited. On physical examination, the right upper extremity is externally rotated and slightly abducted. Palpation of the right shoulder joint shows tenderness and an empty glenoid fossa. The right humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process. The left upper extremity appears normal. Radial pulses are palpable bilaterally. An x-ray of the right shoulder is performed. The physician administers analgesia and obtains informed consent for closed reduction. This patient is at greatest risk for which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Klumpke palsy is typically caused by traumatic injury to the C8 and T1 nerve roots that form the lower trunk of the brachial plexus and manifests with paralysis of the wrist flexors and intrinsic hand muscles. The brachial plexus and its trunks lie more proximal than the nerve typically injured during a shoulder dislocation; therefore, plexus injuries due to shoulder dislocation or reduction are rare. In adults, lower brachial plexus injury most commonly occurs due to hyperabduction of the arm, e.g., during an attempt to break a fall from a height by grabbing support.

B) INCORRECT:

The musculocutaneous nerve is well-protected throughout its course and is rarely injured. Most musculocutaneous pathologies occur as a result of traumatic compression of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. The brachial plexus and its trunks lie more proximal than the nerve typically injured during shoulder dislocation; therefore, plexus injuries due to shoulder dislocation or reduction are rare.

C) INCORRECT:

Proximal median nerve injury can be caused by supracondylar humerus fracture and manifests with an inability to flex the thumb, index, and middle fingers (hand of benediction sign). Median nerve injury is very unlikely to occur in anterior shoulder dislocation or as a complication of reduction because the median nerve runs inferiorly to the shoulder joint.
Image Description:

AI nerve: anterior interosseous nerve

D) CORRECT:

Axillary nerve injury (ANI) is the most common nerve injury associated with shoulder dislocation because of the close proximity of the axillary nerve to the humeral head. ANI is most commonly caused by the dislocation itself but, rarely, can also occur as a complication of closed reduction, which is the first-line treatment for most patients with shoulder dislocation. Typical manifestations of ANI include decreased sensation over the lateral shoulder and impaired abduction and external rotation of the arm. In shoulder dislocation, impaired abduction and external rotation may occur because of mechanical reasons and are not necessarily a sign of ANI. Because ANI has a high rate of spontaneous recovery, patients are initially managed conservatively following closed reduction and immobilization.

Other complications of shoulder dislocation include axillary artery and vein injury, fractures of the shoulder joint, and rotator cuff tears, all of which, rarely, can also occur as a complication of closed shoulder reduction.

Key learning point: Anterior shoulder dislocation most commonly injures the axillary nerve, leading to impaired shoulder abduction and decreased sensation over the lateral deltoid.
Image Description:

Lateral and ventral view of the right shoulder

The dashed line shows the normal position and the solid red line shows the pathological position that occurs with anterior dislocation. Axillary nerve palsy is a known complication of both shoulder dislocation and reduction. Axillary nerve function should be evaluated before and after attempting reduction, by testing sensation over the lateral surface of the shoulder (yellow overlay).

E) INCORRECT:

Radial nerve injury can be caused by humeral shaft fracture and manifests with decreased sensation in the thumb, index, and middle fingers, together with reduced finger extensor strength and wrist drop. Signs of shaft fracture include severe local pain and swelling, deformity, crepitus, and shortening of the arm (if displacement is present). This patient's presentation is most consistent with anterior shoulder dislocation, which rarely results in radial nerve injury. In addition, radial nerve injury is not a complication of closed shoulder reduction.
Image Description:

Motor deficits:
- Wrist drop: inability to extend (dorsiflex) the wrist
- Inability to extend the fingers at the MCP joints

Sensory deficits:
- Dorsal aspect: radial 2½ fingers (less commonly, 3½ fingers), excluding the tips of the 2nd and 3rd fingers. The 1st web space is the autonomous sensory zone of the radial nerve and is highlighted in red.
- Palmar aspect: the radial border of the thumb

Proximal lesion: complete loss of motor and sensory function
Distal lesion (radial tunnel syndrome): partial loss of motor function; preservation of sensory function
questions.hint: This patient presents after trauma with external rotation and abduction of the arm, in combination with shoulder pain and palpation of the humeral head below the coracoid process, indicating anterior shoulder dislocation. This is the most common type of shoulder dislocation.

questions.text:
A 29-year-old man presents to the Emergency Department after a witnessed tonic-clonic seizure. He has a history of epilepsy. He complains of severe shoulder pain and difficulty moving his arm. Examination shows a prominent posterior shoulder bulge with the arm held in adduction and internal rotation. Strength testing is limited by pain. Sensation and distal pulses are intact (see report).
Plain radiographs: Abnormal humeral head contour without obvious anterior displacement
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Anterior shoulder dislocations typically present with the arm in slight abduction and external rotation, with the humeral head palpable anteriorly. Radiographs usually show anterior displacement. The clinical presentation of a posterior bulge and the arm in adduction and internal rotation, along with the seizure mechanism, are inconsistent with anterior dislocation.

B) INCORRECT:

A surgical neck fracture is usually due to direct trauma, presenting with localized tenderness and potential neurovascular compromise. The arm's position in adduction and internal rotation with a posterior bulge is not typical for this fracture. Radiographs would show a fracture line, not just an abnormal humeral head contour.

C) CORRECT:

Posterior shoulder dislocations often occur after seizures due to forceful contractions of the internal rotator muscles, pushing the humeral head backward. This condition manifests with shoulder pain, a prominent posterior bulge, and the arm held in adduction and internal rotation. Radiographs may show an abnormal humeral head contour without clear anterior displacement. Additional imaging, such as axillary or scapular lateral views, is essential for confirmation.

Key learning point: Posterior shoulder dislocations are associated with seizures and present with the arm in adduction and internal rotation, with the humeral head displaced posteriorly, often under the acromion.
Image Description:

X-ray shoulder (AP view; left: dislocation; right: post reduction)

Internal rotation of the humerus during posterior dislocation produces a contour resembling a lightbulb on the AP radiograph (overlay). In addition, poor congruency of the humeral head with the glenoid is seen in this patient. After reduction, the greater tubercle (tuberosity) is visible laterally and the humeral head is well-aligned with the glenoid fossa.

D) INCORRECT:

Acromioclavicular joint separation results from direct trauma to the lateral shoulder, causing pain and tenderness over the AC joint. The clinical findings of a posterior shoulder bulge and the arm in adduction and internal rotation suggest an injury involving the humeral head, not the AC joint.

questions.text: A 24-year-old man presents to the emergency department with pain and inability to move his left arm after falling onto his outstretched left hand while playing basketball. On examination, the patient holds his left arm in a slightly abducted and externally rotated position. There is loss of sensation over the lateral aspect of the left shoulder. Distal pulses and left forearm and finger movements are intact. Anteroposterior and lateral x-rays of the left shoulder are shown. Which of the following anatomical features best explains the injury that occurred in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

The transverse humeral ligament spans the bicipital groove to hold the long head of biceps tendon in place. Laxity here can lead to biceps-tendon subluxation, but does not permit glenohumeral joint dislocation. The static stabilizers of the glenohumeral joint include the fibrous joint capsule reinforced by the glenohumeral ligaments and coracohumeral ligaments, and the coracoacromial arch.

B) INCORRECT:

The lower triangular space (triangular interval), which is bounded by the teres major, humerus, and long head of the triceps, contains the radial nerve and deep brachial artery, not the axillary nerve. The axillary nerve travels through the quadrangular space.

C) INCORRECT:

The glenohumeral joint is a ball-and-socket joint, which has 3 degrees of freedom (flexion-extension, internal-eternal rotation, and abduction-adduction). A modified hinge joint (e.g., tibiofemoral joint) is a type of synovial joint that is a combination of a hinge and pivot joint; it allows only two degrees of freedom (flexion-extension & internal-eternal rotation). Joints with fewer degrees of freedom and a high degree of congruency between the articulating surfaces are inherently more stable.

D) CORRECT:

The stability of a synovial joint depends largely on the depth and congruency of its articular surfaces. The glenohumeral joint is a ball-and-socket joint that has a large articular head (humerus head) and a comparatively shallow socket (glenoid fossa) covering only one-third of the articular head even with the fibrocartilaginous glenoid labrum. This anatomical feature favors mobility over stability and predisposes to dislocation. By contrast, the hip joint’s deep acetabulum covers approximately half of the femoral head and is further secured by an intracapsular ligament (ligamentum teres), conferring markedly greater inherent stability. Forced arm abduction and external rotation (e.g., during a fall on an outstretched hand) can lever the humeral head anteriorly, tearing the inferior capsule. To compensate for this limited bony restraint, the shoulder relies on static stabilizers (the joint capsule, reinforced by the glenohumeral and coracohumeral ligaments) and dynamic stabilizers (the rotator cuff muscles – supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis – and the long head of the biceps tendon).

Key learning point: The shallow socket of the glenohumeral joint makes it more mobile but less stable.
Image Description:

Lateral and ventral view of the right shoulder

The dashed line shows the normal position and the solid red line shows the pathological position that occurs with anterior dislocation.

E) INCORRECT:

The glenohumeral joint is dynamically stabilized by rotator cuff muscles (supraspinatus, infraspinatus, teres minor, subscapularis) and the long head of the biceps. The rhomboid major and minor muscles are scapulothoracic muscles that move and stabilize the scapula, not the glenohumeral joint.
questions.hint: Shoulder dislocation can injure the axillary nerve, which travels around the surgical neck of the humerus and innervates the deltoid, teres minor, and skin over the lateral shoulder (regimental badge area). A fall on an outstretched hand causing inability to move the arm, a fixed deformity in an abducted and externally rotated position, and the findings on the x-ray are consistent with anterior shoulder dislocation. The glenohumeral joint is disrupted in shoulder dislocation.

questions.text: You are seeing a 17-year-old girl who presents with mild but persistent deep, dull, achy pain in her right shoulder one week after dislocating it during a skiing accident. She underwent successful reduction, confirmed by postreduction radiographs, and was discharged with a sling. On examination, she has full range of motion in the shoulder, but there is a sensory deficit over the posterior deltoid and some weakness with resisted arm abduction. Her drop arm test is negative. There is no point tenderness. She is able to extend her wrist and fingers without difficulty. Cervical spine examination is unremarkable. Which one of the following diagnoses is most likely in this case?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

C7 radiculopathy would not manifest with deltoid weakness. Patients with a C7 radiculopathy complain of numbness in the second and third fingers, weakness with resisted wrist extension, or both.

B) INCORRECT:

A negative drop arm test makes a complete supraspinatus rotator cuff tear unlikely.

C) CORRECT:

Anterior shoulder dislocation can injure the axillary nerve, which runs inferior to the humeral head. Axillary nerve injury manifests with deltoid muscle weakness and numbness of the posterior shoulder. Older age, delayed relocation, and humeral head fractures are risk factors for nerve injury after shoulder dislocation.

Anterior inferior dislocations, the most common type of shoulder dislocation, are most closely associated with axillary nerve injury. Affected patients often present with deep aching in the posterior shoulder.

Key learning point: The most likely diagnosis for a patient who presents with deep posterior shoulder pain and deltoid weakness following a shoulder dislocation is axillary nerve injury.

D) INCORRECT:

Although the radial nerve can be injured in an anterior shoulder dislocation, such an injury would manifest clinically as weakness on examination of wrist and finger extension.

E) INCORRECT:

Acute brachial radiculitis (Parsonage-Turner syndrome) is characterized by abrupt onset of unilateral shoulder pain, which becomes progressively painful with worsening neurologic deficits. It is often self-limited. It can manifest similarly to axillary nerve injury after a trauma, such as shoulder dislocation, but it is far less common after shoulder dislocation than axillary nerve injury is. Acute brachial radiculitis is often seen postoperatively and is poorly understood.
questions.hint: This patient most likely had an anterior shoulder dislocation.

questions.text: You are seeing a 23-year-old man who is brought to the emergency department 30 minutes after being tackled while playing football. He has severe right shoulder pain and is unable to move the shoulder. He also reports nausea but has not vomited. On examination, his right upper extremity is externally rotated and slightly abducted. There is tenderness and an empty glenoid fossa on palpation of the right shoulder joint, and the right humeral head is palpated below the coracoid process. The left upper extremity is normal. Radial pulses are palpable bilaterally. An x-ray of the right shoulder is performed. You administer analgesia and obtain informed consent for closed reduction. This patient is at greatest risk for which one of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Radial nerve injury can be caused by humeral shaft fracture and manifests with decreased sensation in the thumb, index, and middle fingers, together with reduced finger extensor strength and wrist drop. Signs of shaft fracture include severe local pain and swelling, deformity, crepitus, and shortening of the arm (if displacement is present). This patient's presentation is most consistent with anterior shoulder dislocation, which rarely results in radial nerve injury. In addition, radial nerve injury is not a complication of closed shoulder reduction.

B) INCORRECT:

Proximal median nerve injury can be caused by supracondylar humerus fracture and manifests with an inability to flex the thumb, index, and middle fingers (hand of benediction sign). Median nerve injury is very unlikely to occur in anterior shoulder dislocation or as a complication of reduction because the median nerve runs inferiorly to the shoulder joint.

C) CORRECT:

Axillary nerve injury (ANI) is the most common nerve injury associated with shoulder dislocation because of the close proximity of the axillary nerve to the humeral head. ANI is most commonly caused by the dislocation itself but, rarely, can also occur as a complication of closed reduction, which is the first-line treatment for most patients with shoulder dislocation. Typical manifestations of ANI include decreased sensation over the lateral shoulder and impaired abduction and external rotation of the arm. In shoulder dislocation, impaired abduction and external rotation may occur because of mechanical reasons and are not necessarily a sign of ANI. Because ANI has a high rate of spontaneous recovery, patients are initially managed conservatively following closed reduction and immobilization.

Other complications of shoulder dislocation include axillary artery and vein injury, fractures of the shoulder joint, and rotator cuff tears, all of which, rarely, can also occur as a complication of closed shoulder reduction.

Key learning point: Anterior shoulder dislocation most commonly injures the axillary nerve, leading to impaired shoulder abduction and decreased sensation over the lateral deltoid.
Image Description:

Lateral and ventral view of the right shoulder

The dashed line shows the normal position and the solid red line shows the pathological position that occurs with anterior dislocation. Axillary nerve palsy is a known complication of both shoulder dislocation and reduction. Axillary nerve function should be evaluated before and after attempting reduction, by testing sensation over the lateral surface of the shoulder (yellow overlay).

D) INCORRECT:

Klumpke palsy is typically caused by traumatic injury to the C8 and T1 nerve roots that form the lower trunk of the brachial plexus and manifests with paralysis of the wrist flexors and intrinsic hand muscles. The brachial plexus and its trunks lie more proximal than the nerve typically injured during a shoulder dislocation; therefore, plexus injuries due to shoulder dislocation or reduction are rare. In adults, lower brachial plexus injury most commonly occurs due to hyperabduction of the arm, e.g., during an attempt to break a fall from a height by grabbing support.

E) INCORRECT:

The musculocutaneous nerve is well-protected throughout its course and is rarely injured. Most musculocutaneous pathologies occur as a result of traumatic compression of the upper trunk of the brachial plexus. The brachial plexus and its trunks lie more proximal than the nerve typically injured during shoulder dislocation; therefore, plexus injuries due to shoulder dislocation or reduction are rare.
questions.hint: This patient presents after trauma with external rotation and abduction of the arm, in combination with shoulder pain and palpation of the humeral head below the coracoid process, indicating anterior shoulder dislocation. This is the most common type of shoulder dislocation.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents with severe left shoulder pain after falling while snowboarding. The arm is held in abduction and external rotation, with a palpable indent at the shoulder. Initial neurovascular examination shows intact sensation and 2+ radial and ulnar pulses. X-ray is shown. Following closed reduction and immobilization, what is the most critical next step?

choices.text: Obtain MRI to evaluate for soft tissue injuries
Apply ice pack and administer oral analgesics
Discharge with shoulder immobilizer and orthopedic follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

MRI is not indicated for routine post-reduction evaluation of uncomplicated shoulder dislocations. MRI may be considered later if Hill-Sachs or Bankart lesions are identified on x-ray imaging but should not delay immediate post-reduction assessment.

B) INCORRECT:

Pain management is important but secondary to ensuring successful reduction and no complications. The critical step is confirming successful reduction and ruling out post-reduction complications.

C) INCORRECT:

While discharge with immobilization and follow-up is appropriate, it should only occur after confirming successful reduction and ruling out post-reduction complications through repeat neurovascular examination and imaging.

D) CORRECT:

Correct -- Post-reduction neurovascular examination and repeat imaging are essential to evaluate successful reduction and identify complications such as Hill-Sachs lesions, fractures that may have occurred during reduction, or new neurovascular injuries. This assessment must be completed before discharge.

E) INCORRECT:

Physical therapy is part of long-term rehabilitation but is not the immediate priority. Early mobilization may increase the risk of redislocation before adequate healing and should be delayed until appropriate follow-up.

questions.text: A 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department with severe right shoulder pain after a fall during a rugby match. He states he landed on his outstretched arm, which was forced backward. On examination, his arm is held in slight abduction and external rotation. The acromion is prominent, and there is a palpable anterior bulge in the subcoracoid region. A neurologic deficit is suspected. This deficit would most likely result in weakness of which of the following actions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Forearm flexion is primarily mediated by the brachialis and biceps brachii muscles, which are innervated by the musculocutaneous nerve. Although the musculocutaneous nerve can be injured in a shoulder dislocation, this is a much less common complication than an axillary nerve injury, and it does not course around the surgical neck of the humerus.

B) INCORRECT:

Wrist extension is controlled by muscles in the posterior forearm, which are innervated by the radial nerve. The radial nerve is most commonly injured in mid-shaft humeral fractures as it travels in the radial groove, not in anterior shoulder dislocations.

C) INCORRECT:

Finger adduction is performed by the palmar interossei muscles, which are innervated by the deep branch of the ulnar nerve. The ulnar nerve is most susceptible to injury at the elbow (cubital tunnel) or wrist (Guyon canal), not at the shoulder joint in this type of injury.

D) CORRECT:

The nerve that courses around the surgical neck of the humerus is the axillary nerve (C5, C6), which is the most frequently injured nerve in an anterior shoulder dislocation. The axillary nerve provides motor innervation to the deltoid muscle and the teres minor muscle. The deltoid is the primary muscle responsible for arm abduction from 15°–90°. Therefore, an axillary nerve injury results in weakness of this action. A common associated finding is loss of sensation over the lateral shoulder, often called the 'regimental badge' area.

E) INCORRECT:

Thumb opposition is primarily a function of the opponens pollicis muscle, which is innervated by the recurrent branch of the median nerve. A median nerve injury is not a typical complication of an anterior shoulder dislocation and is not associated with the anatomy described.
questions.hint: This patient's presentation is classic for an anterior shoulder dislocation. The axillary nerve is the most commonly injured nerve in this type of injury.
